persona.name: Taylor Rivera

occupation.title: Senior Urban Planner / Sustainability Coordinator
occupation.organization: Portland Bureau of Planning and Sustainability (city government)
occupation.description: Full-time municipal urban planner focused on neighborhood-scale climate adaptation projects and development review. Responsibilities include reviewing permit applications for compliance with green building incentives, leading community outreach workshops, preparing staff reports for planning commissions, grant-writing for pilot green infrastructure projects, coordinating across transportation and housing departments, and mentoring junior planners. Regularly uses GIS to analyze land use, FEMA flood maps, and impervious surface data; prepares presentations for public hearings; negotiates with developers to include affordable units and on-site stormwater treatment; and monitors project budgets and timelines. Strong emphasis on translating technical data into accessible language for community members. Balances technical knowledge (hydrology basics, zoning code interpretation, environmental policy) with soft skills (public facilitation, conflict resolution). Occasionally works evenings for community meetings and attends weekend site visits.

persona.gender: Cisgender woman (identifies with female assigned at birth)
persona.education: Bachelor of Arts in Environmental Studies with a minor in Economics, University of Oregon. Completed a capstone on equitable green infrastructure funding and a summer internship with the county planning department focused on stormwater management. Took continuing education courses in Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and public engagement facilitation.
long_term_goals: Help shape equitable, climate-resilient urban neighborhoods where affordable housing and green infrastructure coexist.
Be financially independent and own a modest, energy-efficient home paid off by mid-50s.
Develop a community land trust or partner with one to secure permanently affordable housing in Portland.
Write a practical guide for community groups about navigating municipal planning processes.
Mentor younger planners from underrepresented backgrounds and create internship pipelines.
Run for local office (city council or planning commission) in the next decade to influence policy directly.
Learn advanced GIS modeling and hydrology to better integrate green stormwater infrastructure in planning projects.
Cultivate a small, self-sustaining urban garden and a habit of seasonal canning and preserving produce.
Travel to Northern Europe and Japan to study low-carbon urban systems and transit-oriented development.
Maintain a balanced life that includes consistent friendships, hobbies, and good mental health practices.

style.general_tone: Measured, pragmatic, and warm with occasional dry humor. Communicates in clear, accessible language and avoids jargon when speaking to community groups; uses technical terms with peers.
style.speech_and_accent: Pacific Northwest American English with relaxed intonation, slight tendency to soften the end of sentences. Uses 'we' language in group settings. When stressed, speech becomes faster and clipped.
style.mannerisms: Often steeples fingers when thinking, tilts head slightly before asking clarifying questions, and maintains steady eye contact. Has a habit of carrying a stainless steel water bottle and a worn Moleskine notebook, which she consults mid-conversation. When explaining plans, uses hand gestures to illustrate spatial relationships.
style.formality: Prefers business-casual in professional settings. In community meetings adopts a welcoming, informal posture to put people at ease. Email tone is concise, courteous, and occasionally uses bullet points for clarity.
style.digital_style: Writes clear, structured emails and Slack messages. Creates slide decks with a consistent visual aesthetic—clean fonts, readable charts, muted green/blue palette. Prefers data visualizations that highlight equity impacts.
style.conflict_style: Pragmatic mediator: seeks common ground, frames trade-offs explicitly, and documents agreements. Can be assertive when advocating for climate measures; not confrontational but persistent.
style.social_style: Warm with familiar colleagues, reserved with strangers at first, gradually expressive once trust is built. Small-group oriented rather than large-party person.
style.humor: Dry, slightly sarcastic; uses self-deprecating remarks to defuse tension.
style.attention_to_detail: High; expects follow-through and clear milestones, but tolerates some ambiguity during early-stage projects.
style.presentation_preferences: Uses a mix of maps, simple charts, and short personal stories from community members to make a case; avoids overwhelming slides with text.

traits: Deliberate — thinks through options before committing.
Empathetic — centers the concerns of neighborhoods most affected by climate impacts and displacement.
Idealistic in values but pragmatic in methods: seeks incremental wins.
Organized — keeps meticulous to-do lists and timelines.
Resilient — tolerates long public processes and bureaucratic obstacles.
Perfectionist about public-facing documents, less so in private life.
Curious — enjoys learning new technical tools (GIS, data visualization).
Anxious under sustained uncertainty, especially around job stability and civic erosion.
Collaborative — prefers coalition-building to top-down mandates.
Private about personal struggles but open about professional setbacks when helpful to others.
Witty in small doses; uses humor to bond with teammates.
Skeptical of ideological purity — values evidence and incremental policy.
Generous with time for mentees and community volunteers.

big_five.openness: High. Enjoys new ideas, travel, learning different planning philosophies, and creative problem solving.
big_five.conscientiousness: High. Very disciplined about follow-up, deadlines, and documentation.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-Low. Comfortable speaking in public and leading meetings but prefers one-on-one or small groups for deeper connection.
big_five.agreeableness: Medium-High. Cooperative and compassionate, but willing to push back when fairness or evidence is at stake.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Experiences worry and occasional sleeplessness during project crunches and when civic institutions feel threatened, but generally manages stress with rituals.

Community-led housing models and land trusts
Biking and multimodal transportation advocacy
Local food systems and farmers' markets

Coffee roasts that are medium-dark, single-origin when possible

Civic conversations grounded in data and empathy
Clear, actionable meeting minutes following public events
Public spaces that prioritize shade and seating
Compact, walkable neighborhoods

Maps that tell a story without being cluttered
Mentoring interns and seeing them succeed
Small houseplants on a sunny windowsill
Neighborhood potlucks and block parties
Reusable containers and low-waste living

Good headphones for concentration

Books with both theory and applied case studies
Podcasts that include practitioner interviews
Walking meetings when the weather permits
Locally run coffee shops over big chains for ambiance
Bike-commuting when schedules and weather allow

Knowing where the closest public drinking fountain is
Early morning quiet hours to get substantive work done

Poorly maintained sidewalks and curb ramps
Office food culture heavy on single-use plastics

Intransigence from development stakeholders when evidence is clear

favorite_podcasts: Latina to Latina (for community stories and perspectives)
favorite_shows_and_movies: Documentaries about cities and climate (e.g., 'The Human Scale')
Independent films set in Portland and the Pacific Northwest
music_preferences: Folk and indie artists, local Portland bands
Occasional electronic ambient playlists for focused work
reading_habits: Reads a mix of policy papers, local reporting, and fiction
Subscribes to a regional planning journal and a local newspaper
Keeps a short reading list for the month (usually 4-6 items)
entertainment_and_media.screen_and_social_media: Moderate screen time with a mixture of broadcast and streaming services and less social media dependence. Uses Twitter/X selectively for professional networks and follows municipal accounts; uses Instagram to follow local artists and gardens; avoids endless scrolling, sets limits on evening phone time.

beliefs: Climate change is a present, accelerating threat that requires immediate municipal action.
Cities can and should be designed to reduce vulnerability to extreme weather.
Housing is a human right and displacement must be actively prevented in planning processes.
Equity must be explicitly measured in policy outcomes, not just an afterthought.
Public engagement must be accessible in time, language, and format to be legitimate.
Data-driven decisions are necessary but must be balanced with lived experience.
Green infrastructure (bioswales, permeable pavement, street trees) delivers multiple community benefits beyond stormwater management.
Affordable housing can be integrated into climate projects if paired with funding and policy tools.
Incremental policy change is often more achievable and durable than sweeping overnight reforms.
Local government has meaningful levers—zoning, permitting, incentives—to advance sustainability.
Public-private partnerships can be useful but must be structured to protect community interests.
Gentrification is often an unintended consequence of sustainability investments and must be mitigated.
Community land trusts and cooperatives are viable tools to preserve affordability.
Public transit investment should prioritize frequency and reliability over flashy infrastructure.
Biking infrastructure must be safe, continuous, and equitable to be effective.
Democracy is somewhat threatened by polarization, misinformation, and weakening civic norms.
Civic institutions need transparency and accountability to maintain public trust.
Elected officials should be responsive to both short-term constituent needs and long-term stewardship responsibilities.
Gun safety measures (closing gun show loophole and red flag laws) are reasonable, evidence-based policy to reduce harm.
Local policies can contribute meaningfully to emissions reductions even if national action is slow.
Economic growth should not be pursued at the expense of livability and environmental health.
Markets need smart regulation to prevent speculative pressures on housing.
Investing in community-based organizations yields better, culturally relevant outcomes.
Public budgets should prioritize preventive measures (e.g., flood mitigation) that reduce future costly crises.
Design that centers accessibility creates better places for everyone.
Technology and data collection should protect privacy and avoid surveillance of vulnerable populations.
Voluntary corporate commitments are insufficient; enforceable standards and oversight are necessary.
Education about climate risk must be paired with material supports for adaptation.
Political compromise is necessary; ideological purity can stall progress on urgent issues.
Personal lifestyle changes matter but systems-level changes create scale and justice.
Trust in democracy is built through consistent, meaningful civic participation opportunities.
Local media plays a critical role in informing neighborhoods and holding institutions accountable.
Good planning requires listening first, proposing second.
Resilience investments should be distributed to historically marginalized neighborhoods first.
Public spaces that incorporate art and local culture strengthen community identity.
Funding mechanisms should be flexible to support small grassroots projects as well as larger capital work.
Interdepartmental collaboration (transportation, housing, health, parks) is essential for holistic outcomes.
Professional planners have an ethical duty to avoid greenwashing and to disclose trade-offs openly.
skills: Proficient in QGIS and ArcGIS for spatial analysis and mapping.
Strong grant-writing skills, with two successful applications for neighborhood resilience pilot programs.
Skilled facilitator of community workshops, with techniques for inclusive engagement (translation, childcare coordination, accessible hours).
Able to interpret zoning codes and write clear staff reports and permit conditions.
Competent in Microsoft Office suite and Google Workspace; creates clean, effective slide decks and data tables.
Basic hydrology knowledge applied to stormwater management and green infrastructure planning.
Experience in interagency coordination and building consensus among diverse stakeholders.
Budget management for small-to-medium municipal grants and pilot projects.
Public speaking at planning commission and city council hearings.
Mediation skills for resolving neighborhood conflicts over development proposals.
Familiarity with housing finance tools like tax credits, inclusionary zoning mechanisms, and grants.
Can design and implement community surveys and analyze qualitative feedback.
Project management skills: Gantt charting, milestone setting, and contractor oversight.
Able to translate technical data into plain-language summaries and infographics.
Basic Spanish conversational ability used occasionally in outreach meetings.

general: Carries a reusable water bottle and metal lunch container to minimize waste.
Always brings a printed map to outreach events and annotates it with colored markers.
Checks emails first thing in the morning and again after early-evening community meetings.
Schedules walking site visits on weekday afternoons when possible.
Prefers to schedule 'deep work' blocks in the morning before meetings.
Brings snacks (granola bars, apples) to long-day site visits.
Uses a paper planner plus a digital calendar; syncs both weekly.
Says 'thank you' explicitly after public comments and follows up with FAQs.
Declines invitations to large parties when a work deadline looms.
Volunteers at a neighborhood park clean-up twice a year.

morning: Wakes between 6:15–7:00 AM depending on meeting schedule.
Makes strong coffee (french press on slow days), checks local news headlines and email.
Skims overnight updates from professional networks (planning listservs).
Fills a travel mug and bikes or transit-commutes to the office if weather and schedule permit.
Reviews the day's public meeting materials and prepares a 3-point summary for any presentations.
workday: Starts with a prioritized task list and blocks 90-minute work intervals.
Spends afternoons on mapping, grant narratives, or community engagement planning.
Eats lunch with a small group of colleagues a few times a week to trade project notes.
Returns phone calls from community leaders and sends clear next-step emails.
evening: Attends a neighborhood association meeting or a green infrastructure site tour a few times per month.
Cooks a simple dinner (stir-fry, grain bowls), often while listening to a podcast.
Reviews meeting notes and updates the planner and digital calendar for the next day.
Sets phone to 'do not disturb' after 10:00 PM and reads fiction for 20–45 minutes before bed.
weekend: Goes for a long bike ride or a hike early Saturday.
Visits a farmers' market or a friend-run food cart pod for lunch.
Works a couple of hours on a personal community project (volunteer grant research, neighborhood visioning).
Meets a friend for coffee and casual conversation.
Spends Sunday afternoon doing a mix of chores, home gardening, and light reading.

health.physical: Generally healthy, active lifestyle with regular biking and hiking. Has seasonal allergies and mild exercise-induced asthma controlled with an as-needed inhaler. Slightly nearsighted (wears glasses). Occasional tendonitis in the right wrist from laptop work; practices stretches and ergonomics to manage it.
health.mental: Carries low-level anxiety especially during intense public controversies or budget uncertainty. Practices mindfulness and breathwork occasionally. Sees a therapist sporadically (every few months) for stress management and to process workplace dynamics. Good sleep hygiene most nights but experiences insomnia during crunch periods.
health.medical_history: No chronic diseases, not on daily medications except for an oral allergy antihistamine when needed. Up-to-date on vaccinations. Had minor appendectomy in late teens.
health.fitness: Regular moderate exercise — bikes commute several days a week, does yoga twice a week, and hikes on weekends. Prioritizes walking meetings when possible.
health.nutrition: Mostly plant-forward diet with occasional seafood or poultry. Avoids heavily processed foods. Cooks most meals at home and limits alcohol to weekends (1-2 drinks).
health.self-care: Schedules 'unplug' evenings, occasional mental-health days, and annual solo weekend retreats for reflection and planning.

entries: Mother: Ana Rivera, lives in a nearby suburb, retired elementary school librarian, emotionally close and supportive; weekly phone calls and holiday visits.
Father: Carlos Rivera, small business owner in a neighboring city, pragmatic, emotionally reserved but proud; connects most at family meals.
Sibling: Younger brother, Marco (age 29), lives in Seattle, occasional weekend visits and mutual technical help with home projects; relationship is friendly but not extremely close.
Extended family: A mix of first cousins and aunt/uncle network within the state, gather for major holidays and birthdays.
Close friends: A tight group of 4–6 friends from college and early career—regular dinners, mutual emotional support, occasional collaborative volunteer projects.
Work friends: A cohort of planners and engineers who share technical knowledge and sometimes socialize outside work.
Neighborhood network: Active contacts with two neighbors involved in a community garden and block watch.

Romantic: Single by choice and circumstance, open to long-term partnership but prioritizes career and community goals at the moment; does occasional online dating but prefers meeting through mutual friends or community events.
Mentorship: Mentors two junior planners and advises a local high-school civics program.
Regular collaborators at the transportation bureau, parks department, local nonprofit housing organizations, and state environmental agencies.
Contacts at local universities for student interns and research partnerships.

other_facts: Single and has no children (explicit personal preference and current reality).

Owns a modest 3-bedroom craftsman-style house in an older Portland neighborhood on a mortgage shared with a roommate who helps with utilities; home has modest energy-efficiency upgrades (LED lighting, new insulation in attic).
Has a medium-length tattoo of a stylized oak leaf on the inside of the left forearm that she got during a study abroad trip in college; associates it with resilience and place.

Grew up in a bilingual household (Spanish and English) and uses both languages socially and in outreach occasionally; more comfortable in English professionally but uses Spanish for community meetings with Latinx residents.
First job was as a barista in a neighborhood coffee shop—learned to read people's moods and gained a taste for local coffee culture.
Volunteered in high school on a river cleanup program that sparked early interest in environmental work.
Was student body representative for sustainability initiatives in college and helped get a campus compost pilot started.
Has kept a Moleskine notebook for professional notes and personal reflections since college; some notebooks include sketches of street sections and ideas for community plazas.
Has a small balcony garden with native pollinator plants, a couple of tomato plants in summer, and herbs year-round.
Experienced an intense project burnout five years ago that led to learning better boundary-setting and pacing strategies.
Has a trusted therapist she has seen intermittently for several years; therapy focused on managing perfectionism and public-facing stress.
Prefers public transit and active modes but owns a used hybrid vehicle for errands and out-of-town trips.
Often donates to local causes: park stewardship groups, a tenant defense fund, and a university scholarship for first-generation students.
Has been deposed as an expert witness in one municipal hearing about stormwater mitigation requirements.
Speaks on panels regionally about equitable climate adaptation and has been a guest lecturer at the local university planning program.
Once organized a neighborhood 'visioning' weekend that resulted in a small park pocket renovation; proud of that tangible outcome.
Keeps an emergency kit in her home (basic first aid, flashlight, portable battery, canned food) and advocates for community preparedness.
Has a scar on the left knee from a childhood bicycle accident; tells the story in a self-deprecating way when bonding over outdoor mishaps.
Collects old city planning maps in thrift shops and frames a rotating selection in her living room.
Has a ritual of making a gratitude list at the end of Sundays to center herself for the week ahead.
Loves postcards and writes short ones to close friends when traveling.
Has a favorite bench in a neighborhood park where she goes to read and think.
Once spent a month living in Copenhagen as part of an exchange program studying bicycle infrastructure and still references lessons from that trip.
Works to maintain a modest emergency savings account and tracks expenses carefully in a budgeting app.
Breaks large professional projects into 90-day workplans and shares them with supervisors for accountability.
Prefers to resolve conflict through private conversations before public escalation, when safe and possible.
Has a habit of bringing extra folding chairs to small community meetings so no one has to stand.
Enjoys small rituals—lighting a particular candle while reviewing materials for a big meeting.
Has a collection of cheap rain jackets from thrifting and values function over brand new gear.
Once fostered a short-term rescue dog for a friend; misses the company sometimes but family circumstances prevented adoption.
Is slightly competitive with herself about cycling commute times but values safety over speed.
Has a long-term aspiration to design a neighborhood greenway that integrates stormwater, play space, and affordable housing, and keeps a folder of sketches and reference projects.
Is known in her office for bringing a batch of homemade soup to staff during cold months, which colleagues remember fondly.
Has a vivid memory of a community elder who taught her the importance of listening to stories about place—uses that as a guiding principle in engagement work.
Maintains a 'win list' of small victories (funding awarded, permits adjusted, a lane converted) that helps sustain motivation during slow processes.
Once got lost in a rural county while doing site visits and ended up meeting a farmer who provided coffee and a new perspective on regional infrastructure needs.
Takes a yearly solo retreat, usually a quiet cabin near a lake, to reflect on goals, reset priorities, and sketch ideas without inbox interruptions.
Was once publicly criticized in a local paper for a permitting decision; used the experience to improve transparency and now proactively publishes plain-language decision summaries.
Has a favorite local diner where staff know her order and sometimes leave a note about upcoming neighborhood events.
Keeps a modest social-media presence for professional purposes, curating posts to highlight community stories and project outcomes rather than personal drama.
